document.docTitle: Dariella rubrocuneata Namyatova & Cassis 2021, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Five new genera of the subfamily Cylapinae (Insecta, Heteroptera, Miridae) from Australia

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Five new genera of the subfamily Cylapinae (Insecta, Heteroptera, Miridae) from Australia

mods:name.mods:affiliation: St Petersburg State University, Faculty of Biology, Universitetskaya nab. 7 / 9, St. Petersburg, Russia & University of Tyumen, Volodarskogo ul. 6, Tyumen, Russia & Zoological Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Universitetskaya nab. 1, St Petersburg, Russia
University of New South Wales, Evolution and Ecology Research Centre, School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences, Randwick, Sydney, Australia

figureCitation.captionText: Figure 1. Habitus of Dariella rubrocuneata and Labriella fusca.

Figure 3. SEM images. Dariella rubrocuneata A head and pronotum, lateral view B head and pronotum, dorsal view C head, anterior view D labium E antenna F pleura G legs H trichobothria on hind femur I trichobothria on middle femur J hind tarsus K pretarsus, ventral view L cuneus and membrane cell M scutellum, clavus and corium.

Figure 4. Male genitalia. Dariella rubrocuneata A aedeagus, dorsal view B aedeagus, left lateral view C genital capsule, dorsal view D left paramere, dorsal view E left paramere, posterior view F right paramere, dorsal view G right paramere, posterior view.
Figure 15. Distribution maps A Dariella rubrocuneata, Callitropisca florentine B Labriella fusca, Laetifulvius morganensis, Micanitropis seisia.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Holotype : Australia: Qld
: Mt Boolbun Sth (summit), 15.95°S , 145.1333°E , 950 m, 05 Nov 1995-11 Jan 1996, Monteith, Cook, Roberts, 1♂ (00043357) (QM).
Paratypes : Australia: Qld
: Graham Ra, 17.28333°S , 145.95°E , 550 m, 08 Dec 1995-09 Dec 1995, Monteith, Cook, Thompson, 1♂ (00043361) (QM). Koombooloomba Dam, Upper Tully, 17.8353°S , 145.605°E , 08 Dec 1989, Monteith, Thompson and Janetzki, 1♂ (00043362) (QM). Millaa Millaa Falls, 17.46667°S , 145.6°E , 800 m, 17 May 1995, G. B. Monteith, 1♂ (00045284) (QM). Mt Boolbun Sth (summit), 15.95°S , 145.1333°E , 950 m, 05 Nov 1995-11 Jan 1996, Monteith, Cook, Roberts, 3♂ (00043358, 00043360, 00043359) (QM).

Male. Body length 2.1-2.3. Coloration (Fig. 1 ). Head mostly brown to dark brown, sometimes with reddish tinge; antennal segment I yellow, reddish apically; segments II and III brown; segment IV brown, whitish apically; labium yellow with reddish tinge; pronotum, mesoscutum and scutellum brown to dark brown, often with reddish tinge; pleura mostly brown to dark brown; metathoracic scent gland evaporative area and metapleuron often reddish or with reddish tinge; clavus brown to reddish brown; corium and embolium yellow to pale brown with brown or reddish areas; embolium reddish apically; cuneus red or pale brown with distinct reddish tinge; membrane brown; legs mostly pale brown with red tinge; abdomen reddish brown. Surface and vestiture. See generic description. Structure and measurements . Body ca. 2.6-2.7 x as long as wide, ca. 2.8-3.0 x as long as pronotum width; head ca. 3.6-4.3 x as wide as long; vertex ca. 1.2-1.5 x as wide as eye; anterior view head ca. 1.3-1.4 x as wide as high; antennal segment I ca. 1.1-1.5 x as long as vertex, ca. 0.5-0.6 x as long as head width; segment II ca. 2.4-2.8 x as long as segment I, ca. 3.1-3.7 x as long as vertex, ca. 1.2-1.3 x as long as head width, ca. 0.9-1.0 x as long as pronotum width at base; segment III slightly shorter than segment I, and segment IV almost twice longer than segment III; pronotum ca. 1.7-1.9 x as wide as long, ca. 1.4-1.5 x as wide as head.
Genitalia .
Genital capsule triangular, without supragenital bridge (Fig. 4C ); parameres subequal to each other in size and very similar in shape, slightly curved and with swelling in basal half directed outwards (Fig. 4D-G ); phallotheca stronger sclerotised closer to apex than basally; ductus seminis short, its apical part widened and placed inside endosoma, somewhat sclerotised; endosoma not subdivided into vesica and conjunctiva, voluminous, with sclerotised area placed at right side and armed with small teeth (Fig. 4A, B ).
The specimens were collected with flight intercept trap and pyrethrum knockdown.
The species is named for its red cuneus, ruber from Latin, meaning red.
